alert.note: Alert for Manatee (Florida) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued September 28 at 3:54PM EDT until further notice by NWS Tampa Bay
info.description: ...Forecast flooding changed from Minor to Moderate severity for the following rivers in Florida... Withlacoochee River At Croom affecting Sumter and Pasco Counties. ...Forecast flooding changed from Moderate to Major severity for the following rivers in Florida... Hillsborough River At Morris Bridge affecting Hillsborough County. Manatee River At Rye Bridge affecting Manatee County. For the Withlacoochee...including US 301 Trilby, Croom, SR 200 Holder, US 41 Dunnellon...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Hillsborough...including Morris Bridge, Temple Terrace, Hillsborough River State Park...Major flooding is forecast. For the Manatee...including Myakka Head at SR 64, Rye Bridge...Major flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and major flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Manatee River At Rye Bridge. * WHEN...Until further notice. * IMPACTS...At 17.0 feet, Water reaches the foundations of elevated homes and the Christian Retreat center. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:15 PM EDT Wednesday the stage was 14.5 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 3:15 PM EDT Wednesday was 14.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 15.3 feet just after midnight tonight. - Flood stage is 11.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 15.7 feet on 09/22/1979. - https://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Fld Observed Forecasts (2 pm EDT) Location Stg Stg Day/Time Thu Fri Sat Sun Mon Manatee River Rye Bridge 11.0 14.5 Wed 3 pm 15.2 14.5 13.3 9.0 6.4 &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued as needed.
